awd_titl_txt: Long Term Human Response To Sea Level Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Mark Golitko (University of Notre Dame), with colleagues in Papua New Guinea (PNG), will conduct combined environmental and archaeological survey on the north coast of PNG to assess how people living there responded to rapid climatic and environmental changes during the mid-Holocene period (~7000-3000 years ago). Coastal dwellers are particularly vulnerable to environmental variability and natural disasters, for instance tropical storms and tsunamis. Anticipated increase in environmental variability and rising sea-levels during the coming centuries place many such communities at risk, increasing the likelihood of social unrest and potentially large scale migration out of poorer coastal areas. Predicted climatic changes are analogous to those that occurred during the mid-Holocene period, when marginally warmer global climate inundated many coastal areas. The north coast of New Guinea lies along a tectonically active zone with frequent earthquakes and resultant tsunamis, and is affected by the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) cycle, which produces alternating years of drought and extreme rains. The ENSO cycle intensified during the mid-Holocene at the same time that developing coastal flats may have supported increasing populations. At present, people living in coastal areas of the Southwestern Pacific utilize a variety of risk management strategies, including growing resilient tree crops such as sago palm, and maintaining wide-ranging social ties that can be drawn upon in times of need. The proposed research will examine how people on the north coast of PNG coped with varying levels of ecological risk during the mid-Holocene period, including the antiquity of tree-cropping, extent of social networks, and relative human population levels. 

The research team will use a combined strategy of soiling coring and archaeological survey and excavation. Soil coring will establish changes in environment including evidence of ancient tsunami events. Environmental indicators from core samples (pollen, charcoal) will be used to examine relative changes in population levels and the degree of human impact on forest composition, including the promotion of economic crops like sago palms. Archaeological survey and excavations in rock shelters and along the edges of ancient lagoons will examine the intensity of land use and provide evidence for transport of material culture, indicative of ancient social networks. The mid-Holocene was a period of increased mobility during which time new ideas and practices began to widely circulate in the Southwestern Pacific. Results will indicate how intensely people used the landscape in the context of rapid climatic shifts, how successful they were at mitigating ecological risk, how rapidly population grew, and to what extent these ecological changes may have promoted mobility in the broader Southwestern Pacific. The project will serve as a test case for anticipated outcomes of climatic and environmental change during the coming centuries in similar coastal areas. The project will also generate new ancient climate datasets of use for understanding the ENSO cycle and long-term patterns of climatic variability, as well as understanding the human role in tropical forest composition and conservation. Additionally, the project will provide training to New Guinean archaeologists and US undergraduate and graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project builds on prior NSF funded fieldwork in the Aitape area of northern Papua New Guinea, examining significant climatic and environmental changes that occurred along the northern coast of the island as sea-level rose and then receded during the mid-Holocene period (c. 7000-3000 years ago). A joint US-New Guinean team conducted five weeks of archaeological fieldwork on the coastal flats south of Aitape. During this work, nine four-meter deep sediment cores were collected that document environmental changes on the north coast during the last 6000 years. Additionally, numerous archaeological sites were documented in the area, most of which date to the last 1400 years. Excavations at AIT14-11, a rock shelter previously excavated in 2014, further document longer term human activity in the area dating back as much as 10,000 years ago. Subsequent laboratory analysis of core samples and archaeological materials focused on analyzing charcoal (indicative of fire activity, some caused by people) and chemical biomarkers (preserved leaf waxes that document changes in rainfall and forest composition). The project was heavily delayed by the global pandemic, and results are still being generated, however, preliminary results indicate that the north coast of Papua New Guinea has changed dramatically since the end of the Pleistocene (ice ages) 10,000 years ago. At the end of the ice ages, the coastline was relatively ecologically poor, and was briefly inundated as sea levels rose above modern levels around 7000 years ago. As the sea receded, productive protein-rich lagoons formed after c. 6000 years ago. These lagoons filled in with sediment due to erosion and tectonic uplift further inland over the subsequent 3000 years, but the landscape remaining dynamic and changing until about 1400 years ago, when the current ground surface stabilized. Preliminarily, it appears that population densities likely steadily increased during the mid-Holocene, and by 3000 years ago, there is evidence that people began to heavily clear the tropical forest around Aitape, perhaps to grow more root crops as lagoonal resources became less abundant. This period also coincided with substantial decreases in rainfall amount and predictability (associated with increasing intensity and frequency of the El Ninõ-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) cycle, which may also have contributed to changes in subsistence practices. Around 2700 years ago, fire activity reduced and forest may have regenerated, possibly as people developed subsistence strategies focused more heavily on tree-crops like sago palm, which currently is the made food crop grown in the lowland forests of New Guinea.

Intellectual Merit

The project added significant new information about the prehistory of northern coastal New Guinea, as well as paleoclimate in the region. Archaeologically, knowledge of the north coast of mainland New Guinea is based on excavations at a handful of cave sites as well as surface sites that primarily date to the last 2000 years. This project builds on limited knowledge of archaeology during the early and mid-Holocene in the region. The southwestern Pacific is also an integral component of the ENSO climatic system, which influences temperature and rainfall on both sides of the Pacific. However, there are relatively few robust records of historic ENSO frequency and severity from the western side of the Pacific, and this project therefore provides a valuable new record of paleoclimate. Finally, the project contributes significantly to understanding the long-term role of humans in shaping forest composition in the tropical lowlands of the SW Pacific.

Broader Impacts

The results of this project provide valuable information about how people living on the edge of the southwestern Pacific dealt with significant environmental changes during the last 6000 years, and may be relevant to policy discussions about how to best mitigate future environmental changes in the region. From a conservation standpoint, understanding the role of humans in lowland tropical environments may help in understanding how to best balance ecological diversity and human settlement. The project also provided training for two New Guinean archaeologists, one a student at University of Papua New Guinea. Several US-based students also participated in laboratory analysis of materials recovered during the project and gained experience in archaeological and paleoenvironmental methods. Project fieldwork also raised awareness of archaeology and cultural heritage in communities around Aitape, contributing to the mission of partner institutions in Papua New Guinea.
